Research"],"language":"en","deposited":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,3]],"date-time":"2024-01-03T23:01:17Z","timestamp":1704322877000},"score":33.99746,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.demographic-research.org\/articles\/volume\/50\/1"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,4]]},"references-count":75,"alternative-id":["6252"],"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.4054\/demres.2024.50.1","ISSN":["1435-9871"],"issn-type":[{"value":"1435-9871","type":"electronic"}],"published":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,4]]},"article-number":"1"},{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,30]],"date-time":"2025-06-30T01:40:02Z","timestamp":1751247602177,"version":"3.41.0"},"posted":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,17]]},"group-title":"Computer Science and Mathematics","reference-count":0,"publisher":"MDPI AG","license":[{"start":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,17]],"date-time":"2025-04-17T00:00:00Z","timestamp":1744848000000},"content-version":"unspecified","delay-in-days":0,"URL":"http:\/\/creativecommons.org\/licenses\/by\/4.0"}],"content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"accepted":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,16]]},"abstract":"<jats:p>COVID-19\u2019s effects on mortality are hard to quantify. Issues with attribution can cause problems with resulting conclusions. Analyzing excess mortality addresses this concern and allows for the analysis of broader effects of the pandemic. We propose separate ARIMA models to analyze excess mortality for several countries. For the model of joint excess mortality, we suggest vine copulas with Bayesian pair copula selection. The present study examines weekly mortality data from 2019-2022 in the USA, Canada, France, Germany, Norway, and Sweden. Proposed ARIMA models have low lags and no residual autocorrelation. Only Norway\u2019s residuals exhibited normality, while remaining suggest skewed Student-t distributions as a plausible fit. A vine copula model was then developed to model the association between the ARIMA residuals for different countries, with the countries farther apart geographically exhibiting weak or no association. The validity of fitted distributions and resulting vine copula was checked using 2023 data. Goodness of fit tests suggest that the fitted distributions were suitable, except for the USA, and that the vine copula used was also valid. We conclude that the time series models of COVID-19 excess mortality are viable. Overall, the suggested methodology seems suitable for creating joint forecasts of pandemic mortality for several countries or geographical regions.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.20944\/preprints202504.1478.v1","type":"posted-content","created":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,22]],"date-time":"2025-04-22T00:22:03Z","timestamp":1745281323000},"source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["Copula Modeling of COVID-19 Excess Mortality"],"prefix":"10.20944","author":[{"given":"Jonas","family":"Asplund","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]},{"given":"Arkady","family":"Shemyakin","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]}],"member":"1968","deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,30]],"date-time":"2025-06-30T01:04:35Z","timestamp":1751245475000},"score":29.73902,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.preprints.org\/manuscript\/202504.1478\/v1"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,17]]},"references-count":0,"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.20944\/preprints202504.1478.v1","relation":{"is-preprint-of":[{"id-type":"doi","id":"10.3390\/risks13070119","asserted-by":"subject"}]},"published":{"date-parts":[[2025,4,17]]},"subtype":"preprint"},{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,11,2]],"date-time":"2025-11-02T16:54:59Z","timestamp":1762102499279,"version":"build-2065373602"},"reference-count":0,"publisher":"Asociacion Latinoamericana de Torax","issue":"1","license":[{"start":{"date-parts":[[2024,3,1]],"date-time":"2024-03-01T00:00:00Z","timestamp":1709251200000},"content-version":"unspecified","delay-in-days":0,"URL":"https:\/\/creativecommons.org\/licenses\/by\/4.0"}],"content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"short-container-title":["Respirar"],"abstract":"<jats:p>Introduction: The COVID-19 pandemic caused a significant mortality in the world and in Ecuador. This research aimed to analyze the excess mortality due to the COVID-19 pandemic in Ecuador.\u00a0\nMethod: An observational, longitudinal, quantitative and descriptive study, classified as an ecological study in the field of epidemiology. This study focuses on measuring excess mortality during the years 2020, 2021 and 2022, using the average number of deaths that occurred in the period from 2015 to 2019 as the baseline.\u00a0\nResults: From January 2020 to October 2022, Ecuador accumulated a total excess of deaths of 98,915. In 2020, the excess mortality was higher at 46,374, with the highest value occurring in April at 15,484. In 2021, the excess deaths amounted to 35,859, with April having the highest excess of 7,330. In 2022, the excess mortality was 16,682, with January recording the highest excess at 4,204.\u00a0\nConclusion: Evidence of underreporting of deaths, as well as temporal and geographical variations in excess mortality, was observed. The province with the highest number of deaths and excess mortality was Guayas, followed by Pichincha. The results provide an analysis of the situation during the health emergency, emphasizing the importance of evaluating the healthcare system's capacity to respond during times of crisis and the imperative need to implement corrective measures for the future.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.55720\/respirar.16.1.5","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2024,4,24]],"date-time":"2024-04-24T23:48:58Z","timestamp":1714002538000},"page":"45-58","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":2,"title":["Exceso de mortalidad durante la pandemia de COVID-19 en Ecuador","Excess Mortality during the COVID- 19 pandemic in Ecuador"],"prefix":"10.55720","volume":"16","author":[{"given":"Patricio","family":"Reyes P","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]},{"given":"Milton","family":"Paredes Chicaiza","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]}],"member":"34693","published-online":{"date-parts":[[2024,3,1]]},"container-title":["Respirar"],"link":[{"URL":"https:\/\/respirar.alatorax.org\/index.php\/respirar\/article\/download\/171\/168","content-type":"application\/pdf","content-version":"vor","intended-application":"text-mining"},{"URL":"https:\/\/respirar.alatorax.org\/index.php\/respirar\/article\/download\/171\/180","content-type":"text\/html","content-version":"vor","intended-application":"text-mining"},{"URL":"https:\/\/respirar.alatorax.org\/index.php\/respirar\/article\/download\/171\/168","content-type":"unspecified","content-version":"vor","intended-application":"similarity-checking"}],"deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,7,2]],"date-time":"2025-07-02T14:59:04Z","timestamp":1751468344000},"score":29.622406,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/respirar.alatorax.org\/index.php\/respirar\/article\/view\/171"}},"subtitle":["An\u00e1lisis espacio temporal del exceso de mortalidad durante la pandemia de COVID-19 en Ecuador","Spatiotemporal Analysis of Excess Mortality During the Covid-19 Pandemic in Ecuador."],"issued":{"date-parts":[[2024,3,1]]},"references-count":0,"journal-issue":{"issue":"1","published-online":{"date-parts":[[2024,3,1]]}},"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.55720\/respirar.16.1.5","ISSN":["2953-3414"],"issn-type":[{"type":"electronic","value":"2953-3414"}],"published":{"date-parts":[[2024,3,1]]}},{"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,8,21]],"date-time":"2025-08-21T18:14:41Z","timestamp":1755800081982,"version":"3.44.0"},"reference-count":20,"publisher":"Azerbaijan Medical Journal","issue":"2","content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"abstract":"<jats:p>M\u0259qal\u0259d\u0259 COVID-19 pandemiyas\u0131 il\u0259 \u0259laq\u0259li \u00f6l\u00fcm s\u0259b\u0259bl\u0259rind\u0259n as\u0131l\u0131 olan izafi \u00f6l\u00fcm hadis\u0259l\u0259rinin tezliyini qiym\u0259tl\u0259ndirm\u0259k m\u0259qs\u0259dil\u0259 apar\u0131lm\u0131\u015f t\u0259dqiqat i\u015fi haqq\u0131nda m\u0259lumat verilmi\u015fdir. T\u0259dqiqatda 2018\u20132022-ci ill\u0259r \u00fczr\u0259 Az\u0259rbaycanda \u0259halinin \u00f6l\u00fcm s\u0259viyy\u0259sin\u0259 dair r\u0259smi statistik materiallardan istifad\u0259 edilmi\u015fdir. \u00d6l\u00fcm hallar\u0131n\u0131n art\u0131m tempi, orta illik \u00f6l\u00fcm hallar\u0131 v\u0259 art\u0131q \u00f6l\u00fcm s\u0259viyy\u0259si qiym\u0259tl\u0259ndirilmi\u015fdir. T\u0259dqiqat g\u00f6st\u0259rmi\u015fdir ki, Az\u0259rbaycanda 2019\u20132022-ci ill\u0259r \u0259rzind\u0259 2018-ci ill\u0259 m\u00fcqayis\u0259d\u0259 \u00f6l\u00fcm hallar\u0131n\u0131n art\u0131m tempi 97,7\u2013134,3% interval\u0131nda d\u0259yi\u015fmi\u015fdir. \u018fn y\u00fcks\u0259k art\u0131m tempi b\u0259zi yoluxucu v\u0259 parazitar x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259rl\u0259 (884,4%) \u0259laq\u0259li olmu\u015fdur. 2022-ci ild\u0259 d\u0259 yoluxucu x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259r, sinir sistemi x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259ri v\u0259 d\u0259qiql\u0259\u015fdirilm\u0259mi\u015f s\u0259b\u0259bl\u0259r (simptom v\u0259 sindromlar) n\u0259tic\u0259sind\u0259 \u00f6l\u00fcm s\u0259viyy\u0259si y\u00fcks\u0259k qalm\u0131\u015fd\u0131r. Bel\u0259likl\u0259, Az\u0259rbaycanda COVID-19 pandemiyas\u0131 d\u00f6vr\u00fcnd\u0259 yoluxucu x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259r, t\u0259n\u0259ff\u00fcs sistemi, qan d\u00f6vran\u0131 sistemi, sinir sistemi x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259ri v\u0259 d\u0259qiql\u0259\u015fdirilm\u0259mi\u015f s\u0259b\u0259bl\u0259r n\u0259tic\u0259sind\u0259 \u0259halinin \u00f6l\u00fcm s\u0259viyy\u0259sind\u0259 art\u0131m m\u00fc\u015fahid\u0259 edilmi\u015fdir. Orta illik \u00f6l\u00fcm art\u0131m\u0131 s\u0259viyy\u0259si qan d\u00f6vran\u0131 sistemi x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259ri \u00fczr\u0259 0,828\u2030, yoluxucu x\u0259st\u0259likl\u0259r \u00fczr\u0259 0,566\u2030, d\u0259qiql\u0259\u015fdirilm\u0259mi\u015f s\u0259b\u0259bl\u0259r \u00fczr\u0259 0,122\u2030, b\u00fct\u00fcn s\u0259b\u0259bl\u0259r \u00fczr\u0259 is\u0259 1,95\u2030 olmu\u015fdur.<\/jats:p>\n                                                                                            <jats:p>\u0412 \u0441\u0442\u0430\u0442\u044c\u0435 \u043f\u0440\u0435\u0434\u0441\u0442\u0430\u0432\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0430 \u0438\u043d\u0444\u043e\u0440\u043c\u0430\u0446\u0438\u044f \u043e \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0435\u0434\u0451\u043d\u043d\u043e\u043c \u0438\u0441\u0441\u043b\u0435\u0434\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0438, \u0446\u0435\u043b\u044c\u044e \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u043e\u0433\u043e \u0431\u044b\u043b\u043e \u043e\u0446\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0442\u044c \u0447\u0430\u0441\u0442\u043e\u0442\u0443 \u0441\u043b\u0443\u0447\u0430\u0435\u0432 \u0438\u0437\u0431\u044b\u0442\u043e\u0447\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u0432 \u0441\u0432\u044f\u0437\u0430\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u0441 \u043f\u0430\u043d\u0434\u0435\u043c\u0438\u0435\u0439 COVID-19 \u0432 \u0410\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0431\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0436\u0430\u043d\u0435. \u0412 \u0438\u0441\u0441\u043b\u0435\u0434\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0438 \u0438\u0441\u043f\u043e\u043b\u044c\u0437\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043b\u0438\u0441\u044c \u043e\u0444\u0438\u0446\u0438\u0430\u043b\u044c\u043d\u044b\u0435 \u0441\u0442\u0430\u0442\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0438\u0435 \u0434\u0430\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0435 \u043e \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u043d\u0430\u0441\u0435\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f \u0410\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0431\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0436\u0430\u043d\u0430 \u0437\u0430 2018\u20132022 \u0433\u043e\u0434\u044b. \u0411\u044b\u043b\u0438 \u043e\u0446\u0435\u043d\u0435\u043d\u044b \u0442\u0435\u043c\u043f\u044b \u0440\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0430 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438, \u0441\u0440\u0435\u0434\u043d\u0435\u0433\u043e\u0434\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0435 \u043a\u043e\u043b\u0438\u0447\u0435\u0441\u0442\u0432\u043e \u0441\u043b\u0443\u0447\u0430\u0435\u0432 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u0438 \u0438 \u0443\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043d\u044c \u0438\u0437\u0431\u044b\u0442\u043e\u0447\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438. \u0418\u0441\u0441\u043b\u0435\u0434\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u043f\u043e\u043a\u0430\u0437\u0430\u043b\u043e, \u0447\u0442\u043e \u0432 2019\u20132022 \u0433\u043e\u0434\u0430\u0445 \u043f\u043e \u0441\u0440\u0430\u0432\u043d\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044e \u0441 2018 \u0433\u043e\u0434\u043e\u043c \u0442\u0435\u043c\u043f\u044b \u0440\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0430 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u0432 \u0410\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0431\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0436\u0430\u043d\u0435 \u0432\u0430\u0440\u044c\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043b\u0438 \u0432 \u043f\u0440\u0435\u0434\u0435\u043b\u0430\u0445 \u043e\u0442 97,7% \u0434\u043e 134,3%. \u041d\u0430\u0438\u0431\u043e\u043b\u044c\u0448\u0438\u0439 \u0440\u043e\u0441\u0442 \u043d\u0430\u0431\u043b\u044e\u0434\u0430\u043b\u0441\u044f \u043f\u043e \u0438\u043d\u0444\u0435\u043a\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u043c \u0438 \u043f\u0430\u0440\u0430\u0437\u0438\u0442\u0430\u0440\u043d\u044b\u043c \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u044f\u043c (884,4%). \u0412 2022 \u0433\u043e\u0434\u0443 \u0443\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0435\u043d\u044c \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u043e\u0441\u0442\u0430\u0432\u0430\u043b\u0441\u044f \u0432\u044b\u0441\u043e\u043a\u0438\u043c \u0438\u0437-\u0437\u0430 \u0438\u043d\u0444\u0435\u043a\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0439, \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0439 \u043d\u0435\u0440\u0432\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0441\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0435\u043c\u044b \u0438 \u043d\u0435\u0443\u0442\u043e\u0447\u043d\u0451\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0447\u0438\u043d (\u0441\u0438\u043c\u043f\u0442\u043e\u043c\u044b \u0438 \u0441\u0438\u043d\u0434\u0440\u043e\u043c\u044b). \u0422\u0430\u043a\u0438\u043c \u043e\u0431\u0440\u0430\u0437\u043e\u043c, \u0432 \u043f\u0435\u0440\u0438\u043e\u0434 \u043f\u0430\u043d\u0434\u0435\u043c\u0438\u0438 COVID-19 \u0432 \u0410\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0431\u0430\u0439\u0434\u0436\u0430\u043d\u0435 \u043d\u0430\u0431\u043b\u044e\u0434\u0430\u043b\u043e\u0441\u044c \u0443\u0432\u0435\u043b\u0438\u0447\u0435\u043d\u0438\u0435 \u0443\u0440\u043e\u0432\u043d\u044f \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u043d\u0430\u0441\u0435\u043b\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f \u043e\u0442 \u0438\u043d\u0444\u0435\u043a\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0439, \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u0439 \u0434\u044b\u0445\u0430\u0442\u0435\u043b\u044c\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0441\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0435\u043c\u044b, \u0441\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0435\u043c\u044b \u043a\u0440\u043e\u0432\u043e\u043e\u0431\u0440\u0430\u0449\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f, \u043d\u0435\u0440\u0432\u043d\u043e\u0439 \u0441\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0435\u043c\u044b \u0438 \u043d\u0435\u0443\u0442\u043e\u0447\u043d\u0451\u043d\u043d\u044b\u0445 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0447\u0438\u043d. \u0421\u0440\u0435\u0434\u043d\u0435\u0433\u043e\u0434\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0439 \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0441\u0442 \u0441\u043c\u0435\u0440\u0442\u043d\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u0441\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0430\u0432\u0438\u043b 0,828\u2030 \u043f\u043e \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u044f\u043c \u0441\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0435\u043c\u044b \u043a\u0440\u043e\u0432\u043e\u043e\u0431\u0440\u0430\u0449\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f, 0,566\u2030 \u043f\u043e \u0438\u043d\u0444\u0435\u043a\u0446\u0438\u043e\u043d\u043d\u044b\u043c \u0437\u0430\u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0438\u044f\u043c, 0,122\u2030 \u043f\u043e \u043d\u0435\u0443\u0442\u043e\u0447\u043d\u0451\u043d\u043d\u044b\u043c \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0447\u0438\u043d\u0430\u043c \u0438 1,95\u2030 \u043f\u043e \u0432\u0441\u0435\u043c \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0447\u0438\u043d\u0430\u043c.<\/jats:p>\n                                                    <jats:p>The article provides information on a research study conducted to assess the frequency of excess mortality cases depending on causes of death related to the COVID-19 pandemic in Azerbaijan. The study used official statistical data on mortality levels of the population in Azerbaijan for the years 2018\u20132022. The growth rate of deaths, average annual deaths, and excess mortality levels were evaluated. The study showed that during 2019\u20132022, compared to 2018, the growth rate of deaths in Azerbaijan ranged between 97.7% and 134.3%. The highest growth rate was associated with certain infectious and parasitic diseases (884.4%). In 2022, mortality remained high due to infectious diseases, nervous system diseases, and unspecified causes (symptoms and syndromes). Thus, during the COVID-19 pandemic period in Azerbaijan, an increase in mortality was observed due to infectious diseases, respiratory system diseases, circulatory system diseases, nervous system diseases, and unspecified causes. The average annual increase in mortality was 0.828\u2030 for circulatory system diseases, 0.566\u2030 for infectious diseases, 0.122\u2030 for unspecified causes, and 1.95\u2030 for all causes.<\/jats:p>","DOI":"10.34921\/amj.2025.2.022","type":"journal-article","created":{"date-parts":[[2025,7,31]],"date-time":"2025-07-31T09:35:28Z","timestamp":1753954528000},"page":"137-143","source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["COVID-19 PANDEM\u0130YASININ M\u00dcXT\u018fL\u0130F X\u018fST\u018fL\u0130KL\u018fRL\u018f \u018fLAQ\u018fL\u0130 \u0130ZAF\u0130 \u00d6L\u00dcM R\u0130SK\u0130N\u018f T\u018fS\u0130R\u0130"],"prefix":"10.34921","author":[{"given":"S.\u0130.","family":"\u0130sg\u0259nd\u0259rova","sequence":"first","affiliation":[{"name":"\u018f.\u018fliyev ad\u0131na Az\u0259rbaycan D\u00f6vl\u0259t H\u0259kiml\u0259ri T\u0259kmill\u0259\u015fdirm\u0259 \u0130nstitutu"}]}],"member":"50808","published-online":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,25]]},"reference":[{"key":"1","unstructured":"COVID-19 Excess Mortality Collaborators. Cl\u0131n\u0131cal-\u0131mmunolog\u0131cal man\u0131festat\u0131ons and character\u0131st\u0131cs of mult\u0131system \u0131nflammatory syndrome \u0131n ch\u0131ldren w\u0131th COVID-19 \/\/ Azerbaijan Medical Journal, 2025, No. 1, pp. 17\u201322] https:\/\/doi.org\/10.34921\/amj.2025.1.003","DOI":"10.34921\/amj.2025.1.003"},{"key":"19","doi-asserted-by":"crossref","unstructured":"\u0130sayev C.P., M\u0259mm\u0259dova N.O., Cavadzad\u0259 V.N., Ta\u011f\u0131yeva N.C., M\u0259mm\u0259dova S.C., S\u0259f\u0259rova N.\u018f. SARS-CoV-2 virus infeksiyas\u0131 ke\u00e7irmi\u015f x\u0259st\u0259l\u0259rd\u0259 astenik \u0259lam\u0259tl\u0259rin qiym\u0259tl\u0259ndirilm\u0259si \/\/ \u0410z\u0259rbaycan \u0422ibb Jurnal\u0131, 2025, \u21161, 29-33 [Isayev J.P., Mammadova N.O., V.N.Javadzadeh, Taghiyeva N.C., Mammadova S.C., Safarova N.A. Evaluat\u0131on of asthen\u0131c symptoms \u0131n pat\u0131ents w\u0131th SARS-CoV-2 \u0131nfect\u0131on \/\/ Azerbaijan Medical Journal, 2025, No. 1, pp.29\u201333] https:\/\/doi.org\/10.34921\/amj.2025.1.005","DOI":"10.34921\/amj.2025.1.005"},{"key":"20","unstructured":"\u0421\u0442\u0435\u043d\u0442\u043e\u043d, \u0413. \u041c\u0435\u0434\u0438\u043a\u043e-\u0431\u0438\u043e\u043b\u043e\u0433\u0438\u0447\u0435\u0441\u043a\u0430\u044f \u0441\u0442\u0430\u0442\u0438\u0441\u0442\u0438\u043a\u0430 \u2013 \u041c\u043e\u0441\u043a\u0432\u0430: \u0418\u0437\u0434. \u041f\u0440\u0430\u043a\u0442\u0438\u043a\u0430, -1999. - 459 \u0441. [Stenton, G. Mediko-biologicheskaja statistika \u2013 Moskva: Izd. Praktika, -1999. - 459 p.]"}],"container-title":["Azerbaijan Medical Journal"],"original-title":["THE IMPACT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC ON EXCESS MORTALITY RISK ASSOCIATED WITH VARIOUS DISEASES"],"language":"az","deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,8,20]],"date-time":"2025-08-20T06:18:44Z","timestamp":1755670724000},"score":29.190409,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.azmedjournal.com\/index.php\/amz\/article\/view\/662"}},"subtitle":["\u0412\u041b\u0418\u042f\u041d\u0418\u0415 \u041f\u0410\u041d\u0414\u0415\u041c\u0418\u0418 COVID-19 \u041d\u0410 \u0420\u0418\u0421\u041a \u0418\u0417\u0411\u042b\u0422\u041e\u0427\u041d\u041e\u0419 \u0421\u041c\u0415\u0420\u0422\u041d\u041e\u0421\u0422\u0418, \u0421\u0412\u042f\u0417\u0410\u041d\u041d\u042b\u0419 \u0421 \u0420\u0410\u0417\u041b\u0418\u0427\u041d\u042b\u041c\u0418 \u0417\u0410\u0411\u041e\u041b\u0415\u0412\u0410\u041d\u0418\u042f\u041c\u0418"],"issued":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,25]]},"references-count":20,"journal-issue":{"issue":"2","published-online":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,25]]}},"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.34921\/amj.2025.2.022","ISSN":["0005-2523"],"issn-type":[{"type":"print","value":"0005-2523"}],"published":{"date-parts":[[2025,6,25]]}},{"institution":[{"name":"medRxiv"}],"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2026,1,16]],"date-time":"2026-01-16T11:51:42Z","timestamp":1768564302199,"version":"3.49.0"},"posted":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,22]]},"group-title":"Health Informatics","reference-count":23,"publisher":"openRxiv","license":[{"start":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,22]],"date-time":"2024-01-22T00:00:00Z","timestamp":1705881600000},"content-version":"vor","delay-in-days":0,"URL":"http:\/\/creativecommons.org\/licenses\/by\/4.0\/"}],"content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"accepted":{"date-parts":[[2024,8,12]]},"abstract":"<jats:title>Abstract<\/jats:title>\n                <jats:sec>\n                  <jats:title>Aim<\/jats:title>\n                  <jats:p>This study investigates factors influencing pandemic mortality rates across U.S. states during different waves of SARS-CoV-2 infection from February 2020 to April 2023, given that over one million people died from COVID-19 in the country.<\/jats:p>\n                <\/jats:sec>\n                <jats:sec>\n                  <jats:title>Methods<\/jats:title>\n                  <jats:p>We performed statistical analyses and used linear regression models to estimate age-adjusted and unadjusted excess mortality as functions of life expectancy, vaccination rates, and GDP per capita in U.S. states.<\/jats:p>\n                <\/jats:sec>\n                <jats:sec>\n                  <jats:title>Results and Discussion<\/jats:title>\n                  <jats:p>States with lower life expectancy and lower GDP per capita experienced significantly higher mortality rates during the pandemic, underscoring the critical role of underlying health conditions and healthcare infrastructure, as reflected in these factors. When categorizing states by vaccination rates, significant differences in GDP per capita and pre-pandemic life expectancy emerged between states with lower and higher vaccination rates, likely explaining mortality disparities before mass vaccination. During the Delta and Omicron BA.1 waves, when vaccines were widely available, the mortality gap widened, and states with lower vaccination rates experienced nearly double the mortality compared to states with higher vaccination rates (Odds Ratio 1.8, 95% CI 1.7-1.9, p &lt; 0.01). This disparity disappeared during the later Omicron variants, likely because the levels of combined immunity from vaccination and widespread infection across state populations became comparable. We showed that vaccination rates were the only significant factor influencing age-adjusted mortality, highlighting the substantial impact of age-specific demographics on both life expectancy and GDP across states.<\/jats:p>\n                <\/jats:sec>\n                <jats:sec>\n                  <jats:title>Conclusion<\/jats:title>\n                  <jats:p>The study underscores the critical role of high vaccination rates in reducing excess deaths across all states, regardless of economic status. Vaccination rates proved more decisive than GDP per capita in reducing excess deaths. Additionally, states with lower pre-pandemic life expectancy faced greater challenges, reflecting the combined effects of healthcare quality, demographic variations, and social determinants of health. These findings call for comprehensive public health strategies that address both immediate interventions, like vaccination, and long-term improvements in healthcare infrastructure and social conditions.<\/jats:p>\n                <\/jats:sec>","DOI":"10.1101\/2024.01.21.24301582","type":"posted-content","created":{"date-parts":[[2024,1,22]],"date-time":"2024-01-22T18:52:55Z","timestamp":1705949575000},"source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["Impact of Vaccination Rates, Pre-Pandemic Life Expectancy, Economic Status and Age on COVID-19 Excess Mortality Across United States"],"prefix":"10.64898","author":[{"ORCID":"https:\/\/orcid.org\/0000-0001-8555-9847","authenticated-orcid":false,"given":"Olga","family":"Matveeva","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]},{"given":"Aleksey Y.","family":"Ogurtsov","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]},{"ORCID":"https:\/\/orcid.org\/0000-0003-2272-7473","authenticated-orcid":false,"given":"Svetlana A.","family":"Shabalina","sequence":"additional","affiliation":[]}],"member":"54368","reference":[{"key":"2024081411300901000_2024.01.21.24301582v2.1","first-page":"4138","article-title":"Evaluation of the role of vaccination in the COVID-19 pandemic based on the data from the 50 U","volume":"20","year":"2022","journal-title":"S.
